work.p: Portions of this manuscript were used in Whitman's footnote to "New Themes Entered Upon," Specimen Days & Collect (1882).

titleStmt.title: [I have jotted down these memoranda]
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln
titleStmt.funder: The National Endowment for the Humanities

address.addrLine: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: This is a short prose manuscript that reads like notes towards a preface. However, Whitman appears to have returned to this manuscript at a later date, revising some phrases and suggesting that this scrap is the "best foot note of all for first page."
The following are responsible for particular readings or for changes to this file, as noted: Brett Barney Vanessa Steinroetter Ashley Lawson Nicole Gray

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: "I have written these memoranda"
bibl.orgName: Walt Whitman Collection, The Bancroft Library, University of California, Berkeley
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

add.note: ☞☞? best foot note of all for first page

body.p:
I have
written jotted down
these memoranda in the open air, and done my best to keep them to all the mere simplicity reailty and silent, perhaps non-literary suggestiveness of their themes, largely in hopes they would carry
rays ray
of sun, or breeze from wood, or dash of wavese or smell of
flower, wild-flower, grass or corn,
or hum of bee, or gleam of stars by night, or even mystic snow-flakes falling perhaps to
the many a
denizen
